titleStmt.title: James T. Thomas et al. to Thomas E. Bramlette
CWG5426

availability.p: This image and transcription is publicly accessible. The image appears courtesy of the repository named in the Source Description. The transcription and annotation were undertaken by Kentucky Historical Society staff, volunteers, and interns. If referencing this document title, accession number, and permanent URL.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition
Early Access

msIdentifier.repository: Kentucky Department for Libraries and Archives
msIdentifier.collection: Office of the Governor, Thomas E. Bramlette: Governor's official correspondence file, petitions for pardons, remissions, and respites 1863-1867

body.p: To His Excellency The Governor of Kentucky
The petition of Jane Hull and others respectfully sheweth

That W. J. Hull had now, for more than three years, been in confinement in the Kentucky Penitentiary for felony. We believe that if any length of confinement will work reformation in the human heart, that his confinement is sufficient for that purpose. We believe he is penitent.
We further respectfully state to your Excellency; that the Jane Hull the mother of W. J. Hull is old, feeble, and helplessly poor. That she greatly needs his labor for her support-
We believe he may be pardoned by your Excellency with safety to the interests of society, and with incalculable advantage to his old and widowed Mother, and your petitioners &c &c

Petitioners Names
James T. Thomas
James W. Sewell
Joshua Sewell
J. P. Hill
John Sparks

Humphry Sparks
John S Clark
